snippet: Local leaders say the past six weeks have shown that as much as many residents legitimately fear and distrust the police, the solution must be better policing, not less.
abstract: Dramatic decrease in police presence and subsequent rise in murders in some Baltimore neighborhoods after six officers were charged in death of Freddie Gray is indicative of strained relationship between residents and law enforcement; police union officials say officers are hesitant to do their jobs out of fear they may be prosecuted while community leaders call for strong police force with accountability.

byline.contributor: Timothy Williams contributed reporting from New York, Mitch Smith from Chicago and Axel Gerdau from Baltimore.

lead_paragraph: Local leaders say the past six weeks have shown that as much as many residents legitimately fear and distrust the police, the solution must be better policing, not less.

headline.main: West Baltimore’s Police Presence Drops, and Murders Soar
headline.print_headline: Looking for Gains in Policing, Baltimore Finds Fewer Police
